Racial profiling has no place in Vermont

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

After years of steady progress on immigrants' rights, Vermont is on the verge of making a historic mistake – succumbing to the empty threats of Donald Trump and Jeff Sessions – and we can't let that happen.

Tell Governor Scott to stand up to Trump and keep ICE and Border Patrol out of Vermont law enforcement.

Vermonters are currently protected by a policy that promotes unbiased policing statewide. Vermont's Fair and Impartial Policing (FIP) policy forbids racial profiling and prevents local police from acting as immigration agents.

Over the past few months, however, Vermont officials have been chipping away at this critical policy. Now, to satisfy Trump and Sessions' demands, Vermont's law enforcement leaders have agreed to remove key FIP protections, needlessly jeopardizing the safety of Vermont communities.

For example, the revised FIP policy weakens protections that prevented Vermont police from referring witnesses or victims of crime to ICE for deportation. This is a huge threat to community safety, as individuals who are undocumented – or who have undocumented family members, friends, or neighbors – may not report crimes for fear that interacting with police will land them in ICE custody. Involving local cops in immigration undermines public safety.

Email Governor Scott today to keep Vermont's communities safe by keeping Vermont law enforcement out of the deportation business.

Unless we act, a weakened Fair and Impartial Policing policy will turn Vermont's law enforcement into another cog in Trump's deportation machine. Help us send them a message: our police are supposed to serve and protect, not deport our family, friends, and neighbors.

Sincerely,

Nico Amador
Community Organizer
ACLU of Vermont
